parse.title: School of Chemistry, University of Manchester

text.*:
School of Chemistry, University of Manchester
The School of Chemistry from Brunswick Park
Location Manchester, United Kingdom
Affiliations
  • Faculty of Science and Engineering
  • University of Manchester
Website www.chemistry.manchester.ac.uk

The School of Chemistry at the University of Manchester is one of the largest Schools of Chemistry in the United Kingdom, with over 600 undergraduate and more than 200 postgraduate research students.

The School has comprehensive academic coverage across the chemical sciences and in all the core sub-disciplines of chemistry, with over 120 postdoctoral researchers.

Contents

  • 1 Notable faculty
    • 1.1 Emeritus
  • 2 History of Chemistry in Manchester
    • 2.1 Alumni
  • 3 References

Notable faculty[edit]

Gareth A. Morris is a Professor of Physical Chemistry in the School and a Fellow of the Royal Society (FRS).
Douglas Kell CBE is a Professor of Bioanalytical Science in the School, based at the Manchester Institute of Biotechnology.

As of 2017[update] The School employs 34 full-time Professors and 11 Emeritus Professors[1] including:

  • Nik Koltsoyannis, Head of School, and Professor of Computational and Theoretical Chemistry.
  • Richard Winpenny, Ex-Head of School, and Professor of Inorganic Chemistry.
  • Douglas Kell, CBE,[2][3] Professor of Bioanalytical Science
  • David Leigh,[4][5] FRS, Sir Samuel Hall Chair of Chemistry
  • Gareth A. Morris,[6] FRS, Professor of Physical Chemistry
  • Paul O'Brien CBE FRS, Professor of Inorganic Materials

Emeritus[edit]

John Joule is an Emeritus Professor in the School of Chemistry

The School is also home to a number of Emeritus Professors, pursuing their research interests after their formal retirement[1] including:

  • John Joule,[7] Emeritus Professor
  • William Byers Brown, Emeritus Professor and first Professor of Computational Chemistry in the department

History of Chemistry in Manchester[edit]

Melvin Calvin completed his PhD in the School of Chemistry and was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1961.

Manchester has a long and distinguished history of Chemistry. John Dalton founded modern Chemistry in 1803 with his atomic theory. James Joule pioneered the science of thermodynamics in the 1840s while working in Manchester. Carl Schorlemmer,[8] was appointed the first UK Professor of Organic Chemistry in 1874.

Alumni[edit]

Other distinguished alumni and former staff[9] from the school of Chemistry include:

  • Melvin Calvin,[10] worked in Manchester from 1935 to 1937, awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1961
  • Michael Polanyi,[11] Professor of Chemistry
  • Arthur Harden,[12] awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1929
  • Norman Haworth,[13] awarded Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1937
  • George de Hevesy,[14] awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1943
  • James Lovelock FRS, undergraduate in Chemistry, graduating in 1941
  • John Charles Polanyi, awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1986
  • Robert Robinson[15] awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1947
  • Ernest Rutherford,[16] awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1908
  • Michael Smith, completed PhD in Manchester, awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1993
  • Alexander R. Todd, Baron Todd,[17] awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1957

See also Notable chemists (and biologists) at the University of Manchester
